parameter 1: On the DVD release, Pink Floyd's "Dogs" is replaced. Most of the scene is cut.
parameter 2: The song Herb sings as he walks into the lobby is redubbed on the late 90's redistribution package, and so is his line "Hi Bailey."  to "Hi, babe."
parameter 3: In the 90's redistribution package, Bob Marley's "Survival" is replaced. Venus's announcement, which was originally "Yes, Brother Marley, we are the survivors," has been redubbed to "Yes, that was Brother Marlon and the Surf Riders".
parameter 5: The song Herb sings as he walks into the lobby is redubbed on the late 90's redistribution package, and so is his line "Hi Bailey."  to "Hi, babe."
parameter 6: "Everybody Rock 'n' Roll The Place" by Eddie Money is replaced on the DVD, with some dialogue cut. The episode originally started with Les singing "Heartbreak Hotel"; that scene has also been cut.
parameter 7: "Everybody Rock 'n' Roll The Place" by Eddie Money is replaced on the DVD, with some dialogue cut. The episode originally started with Les singing "Heartbreak Hotel"; that scene has also been cut.
parameter 8: Elvis Costello's "Goon Squad" is replaced on the DVD release. Some footage is also cut.
parameter 9: In the 90's redistribution package, the theme from Gone With The Wind is replaced by generic music when it's played instrumentally, but it's still the same when Johnny and Venus sing it.
parameter 10: In the 90's redistribution package, the first song Johnny plays at the beginning of act 2 (originally a Ray Charles song) has been replaced. This change is also on the DVD release, where "Beast of Burden" by The Rolling Stones has also been replaced by a generic song and part of a scene has been cut.
parameter 11: Elvis Costello's "Goon Squad" is replaced on the DVD release. Some footage is also cut.
parameter 12: "Queen of the Forest" by Ted Nugent (the very first rock song Johnny Fever plays on WKRP) is replaced with generic music on the 90's redistribution package and DVD release. Interestingly, though, except on the DVD release, the Nugent song is intact when the scene is repeated in two other episodes, which proves nothing except that the process of licensing music for this package was pretty haphazard. At least that's Howard Hesseman's real voice saying "booger". In the tag, the song Venus plays, "Dance, Dance, Dance" by Chic, has been replaced.
parameter 13: In the 90's redistribution package, two songs (the ones just before and just after the turkey drop) are replaced.

parameter 38: In the 90's syndication package, some footage is cut from the beginning to eliminate "Suction Prints" by Captain Beefheart and Johnny's corresponding announcement. The Nicolette Larson song that Johnny plays at the end is replaced by a reprise of the WKRP ending theme. Johnny's announcement is also lost.
parameter 39: Elvis Costello's "Goon Squad" is replaced on the DVD release. Some footage is also cut.
parameter 40: "Queen of the Forest" by Ted Nugent (the very first rock song Johnny Fever plays on WKRP) is replaced with generic music on the 90's redistribution package and DVD release. Interestingly, though, except on the DVD release, the Nugent song is intact when the scene is repeated in two other episodes, which proves nothing except that the process of licensing music for this package was pretty haphazard. At least that's Howard Hesseman's real voice saying "booger". In the tag, the song Venus plays, "Dance, Dance, Dance" by Chic, has been replaced.
parameter 41: Elvis Costello's "Goon Squad" is replaced on the DVD release. Some footage is also cut.
parameter 42: In the 90's redistribution package, the opening theme to Real Families is replaced by a different generic theme and thus has a different announcer. All the rock songs that WKRP plays are still present, except that the music that plays while Venus talks about the dancing ducks promotion might be stock music.

parameter 47: A running joke in the original broadcast featured the fanfare from the movie "Patton" played at various times as characters spoke to and about Little Arthur. In syndication this was removed, creating at least two known alterations. In one release the music is just removed completely, and if you listen closely you can still hear a faint echo of it on the soundtrack. In a second version, the music is simply replaced with a generic trumpet fanfare.
parameter 48: All songs replaced in 90's redistribution package and DVD release.
